lines.text: Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: Come, shelter, shelter: I have removed Falstaff's horse, and he frets like a gummed velvet.

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Stand close.
Enter FALSTAFF

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Poins! Poins, and be hanged! Poins!

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Peace, ye fat-kidneyed rascal! what a brawling dost thou keep!

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Where's Poins, Hal?

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: He is walked up to the top of the hill: I'll go seek him.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: I am accursed to rob in that thief's company: the rascal hath removed my horse, and tied him I know not where. If I travel but four foot by the squier further afoot, I shall break my wind. Well, I doubt not but to die a fair death for all this, if I 'scape hanging for killing that rogue. I have forsworn his company hourly any time this two and twenty years, and yet I am bewitched with the rogue's company. If the rascal hath not given me medicines to make me love him, I'll be hanged; it could not be else: I have drunk medicines. Poins! Hal! a plague upon you both! Bardolph! Peto! I'll starve ere I'll rob a foot further. An 'twere not as good a deed as drink, to turn true man and to leave these rogues, I am the veriest varlet that ever chewed with a tooth. Eight yards of uneven ground is threescore and ten miles afoot with me; and the stony-hearted villains know it well enough: a plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to another! Whew! A plague upon you all! Give me my horse, you rogues; give me my horse, and be hanged!
They whistle

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Peace, ye fat-guts! lie down; lay thine ear close to the ground and list if thou canst hear the tread of travellers.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Have you any levers to lift me up again, being down? 'Sblood, I'll not bear mine own flesh so far afoot again for all the coin in thy father's exchequer. What a plague mean ye to colt me thus?

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Thou liest; thou art not colted, thou art uncolted.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: I prithee, good Prince Hal, help me to my horse, good king's son.

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Out, ye rogue! shall I be your ostler?

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Go, hang thyself in thine own heir-apparent garters! If I be ta'en, I'll peach for this. An I have not ballads made on you all and sung to filthy tunes, let a cup of sack be my poison: when a jest is so forward, and afoot too! I hate it.
Enter GADSHILL, BARDOLPH and PETO

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Stand.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: So I do, against my will.

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: O, 'tis our setter: I know his voice. Bardolph, what news?

lines.speaker: bardolph
lines.text: Case ye, case ye; on with your vizards: there 's money of the king's coming down the hill; 'tis going to the king's exchequer.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: You lie, ye rogue; 'tis going to the king's tavern.

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: There's enough to make us all.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: To be hanged.

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Sirs, you four shall front them in the narrow lane; Ned Poins and I will walk lower: if they 'scape from your encounter, then they light on us.

lines.speaker: peto
lines.text: How many be there of them?

lines.speaker: gadshill
lines.text: Some eight or ten.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: 'Zounds, will they not rob us?

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: What, a coward, Sir John Paunch?

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Indeed, I am not John of Gaunt, your grandfather; but yet no coward, Hal.

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Well, we leave that to the proof.

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: Sirrah Jack, thy horse stands behind the hedge: when thou needest him, there thou shalt find him. Farewell, and stand fast.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Now cannot I strike him, if I should be hanged.

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Ned, where are our disguises?

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: Here, hard by: stand close.
Exeunt PRINCE HENRY and POINS

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Now, my masters, happy man be his dole, say I: every man to his business.
Enter the Travellers

lines.speaker: first traveller
lines.text: Come, neighbour: the boy shall lead our horses down the hill; we'll walk afoot awhile, and ease our legs.

lines.speaker: thieves
lines.text: Stand!

lines.speaker: travellers
lines.text: Jesus bless us!

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Strike; down with them; cut the villains' throats: ah! whoreson caterpillars! bacon-fed knaves! they hate us youth: down with them: fleece them.

lines.speaker: travellers
lines.text: O, we are undone, both we and ours for ever!

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Hang ye, gorbellied knaves, are ye undone? No, ye fat chuffs: I would your store were here! On, bacons, on! What, ye knaves! young men must live. You are Grand-jurors, are ye? we'll jure ye, 'faith.
Here they rob them and bind them. Exeunt
Re-enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: The thieves have bound the true men. Now could thou and I rob the thieves and go merrily to London, it would be argument for a week, laughter for a month and a good jest for ever.

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: Stand close; I hear them coming.
Enter the Thieves again

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Come, my masters, let us share, and then to  horse before day. An the Prince and Poins be not two arrant cowards, there's no equity stirring: there's no more valour in that Poins than in a wild-duck.

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Your money!

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: Villains! As they are sharing, the Prince and Poins set upon  them; they all run away; and Falstaff, after a blow or two, runs away too, leaving the booty behind them

lines.speaker: prince henry
lines.text: Got with much ease. Now merrily to horse: The thieves are all scatter'd and possess'd with fear So strongly that they dare not meet each other; Each takes his fellow for an officer. Away, good Ned. Falstaff sweats to death, And lards the lean earth as he walks along: Were 't not for laughing, I should pity him.

lines.speaker: poins
lines.text: How the rogue roar'd!
Exeunt
